content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers and promoting the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in health professions. SEC. 4. SUPPORT FOR INSTITUTIONS COMMITTED TO WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities committed to health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including educational institutions producing underrepresented minority health professionals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to educational institutions historically producing underrepresented minority health professionals, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving schools, tribal colleges, and institutions with programs for minority health professional recruitment and retention. Islander-serving institutions, health professional associations, and institutions located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations are eligible for grants to recruit and retain underrepresented minority health professionals. Islander-serving institutions, health professional associations, and institutions in underrepresented minority communities are eligible for grants to increase workforce diversity by enrolling at least 20% underrepresented minorities. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary as required. Applicants for grants to increase workforce diversity must submit an application to the Secretary containing required information. Funds received are to be used for expanding, implementing, or evaluating workforce diversity programs, with a focus on mental health care professions and minority status consideration. Activities may include educational outreach programs in health professions. Possible activities for workforce diversity programs may include educational outreach, scholarship programs, postbaccalaureate programs, academic enrichment, mentoring, internship programs in health entities. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for grant recipients of workforce diversity programs, including pipeline programs, mentoring, internship programs, community partnerships, and leadership training. Grantees must submit annual reports summarizing their activities. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in this section. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. Eliminating disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, is tasked with addressing disparities in maternity health outcomes. Stakeholder organizations, including national medical specialty groups, maternal child health organizations, minority population representatives, and health disparity organizations, are required to conduct research and expand access to services to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. Expand access to services proven to enhance maternity care for vulnerable populations and establish a demonstration project in 8 selected states to compare and implement effective interventions to reduce disparities in maternity services and outcomes. The Secretary will select more than 8 States based on applications specifying regions and populations to be served under the demonstration project. Criteria will ensure representation of affected communities and test various intervention models. The demonstration project will test various intervention models with an evidence base for effectiveness, in consultation with local provider organizations. It will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. The demonstration project, starting on January 1, 2015, and ending on December 31, 2019, allows for grants to collect data for evaluation and monitoring. States participating must report necessary data to the Secretary. The Secretary requires data on project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care for monitoring. A report on bundled payment selection rationale must be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2020. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress by December 31, 2020, on the results of the demonstration project. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities in health care. The Secretary will establish an education program to inform healthcare professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities in health care through outreach campaigns and dissemination of scientific evidence. The curr_chunk discusses disparities in health care related to various factors such as race, ethnicity, age, disability status, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. It emphasizes the need to disseminate new research findings to healthcare providers and patients to address and eliminate these disparities. The curr_chunk focuses on disseminating information about linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare, ensuring language access services for people with limited-English proficiency, and collecting data on various factors like race, ethnicity, disability status, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. The curr_chunk focuses on designing educational initiatives for healthcare providers, assessing the impact of programs on raising awareness of health disparities, and authorizing appropriations for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
